Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: High Performance I/O Methods and Infrastructures for Large-Scale Geoscience Applications on Supercomputers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to obtain fast I/O using a sustainable, easy-to-use, fast, and portable framework for the largest applications running on high performance computers remains a formidable task. This project researches techniques for two challenges that are faced by the research community in high performance I/O.

1. Fast and scalable I/O that adapts to ever-increasing system complexity in current HPC systems, built with multi-core nodes possessing accelerators and deep memory hierarchies. This research will investigate new techniques to deal with the trends for current-generation supercomputers to use accelerators such as GPGPUs and Intel's Xeon Phi.

2. Sustainable and portable parallel I/O. The project will build on the team's Adaptable I/O System (ADIOS) to develop such an I/O infrastructure that encapsulates research and best practices and can enable scientists to use emerging platforms.

Additional goals are to promote international visibility of the benefits of investment in HPC by demonstrating the capability of ADIOS, and to explore new collaboration mechanisms for international researchers. This research is simultaneously high risk (researching and developing a conceptual solution that can address the I/O challenges faced by large HPC centers when using accelerators) and high reward (this solution will be encapsulated into a sustainable software framework that has a large user base).

POR.DRECONTENT:
We worked with several collaborators to research I/O performance issues, and develop performance fixes and optimizations of the Adios middleware.  This work included integration of Adios with several new applications that had not previously used Adios. These applications include Grapes, a weather simulation of interest to our collaborator, Dr. Wei Xue, as well as an image-processing pipeline of interest to another collaborator, Dr. Lizhe Wang.  Performance testing was done with the Grapes code on the Chinese Supercomputer Tianhe-1a, and we worked with Dr. Xue and his students to optimize the I/O performance of that code.

We also made several software improvements to better facilitate working with remote Adios users such as Dr. Xue and Dr. Wang. There were two key aspects of these extensions. First, we added automatic collection of timing information to Adios output files. This has smoothed our interactions with remote users by allowing us immediate access to diagnostic information for large-scale application runs that would be impractical to rerun for performance testing. Next, we extended the Skel Software with a replay mechanism that uses metadata extracted from Adios output files to be used to generate an application skeleton that mimics the I/O behavior of the application that produced the output. This allows us to troubleshoot performance issues for users without the need to obtain, learn, build, and execute the user’s application. Both of these new software components have been integrated into Adios and released as part of our regular release cycle.
